summary: Clemard Joseph Charles was a Haitian banker and businessman who was a confidant of President Duvalier. He was of interest to the CIA and State Department in the early 1960s. Documents detail interactions with Charles, assessments of his character and business dealings, and inquiries into his potential as a political figure or asset. Later, he became a political prisoner, allegedly involved in anti-government plotting. Intelligence reports and cables from 1969 to 1974 cover his imprisonment, health issues, and attempts to secure his release or medical treatment. There are also details about his financial situation and plots against President Duvalier.
significance: Based on the provided documents, Clemard Joseph Charles's significance in the JFK assassination context is not directly apparent. The documents primarily focus on his role in Haitian politics, his relationship with President Duvalier, and his interactions with U.S. intelligence agencies. There is no mention of any involvement in the JFK assassination.
